contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=January 2013}} '''Monopsychism''' is the belief that all humans share one and the same eternal [[consciousness]], [[Soul (spirit)|soul]], [[mind]] or [[intellect]]. It is a recurring theme in many [[Mysticism|mystical traditions]]. Monopsychism is a doctrine of [[Sabianism]], Jewish [[Kabbalah]], and [[Averroism]], and is also a part of [[Rastafari movement|Rastafarian]] beliefs. A similar belief in some [[mystical]] [[Judeo-Christian-Islamic]] traditions is that all human beings have different souls but once composed a single unified soul in [[Adam]]. ==Aquinas== [[Thomas Aquinas]] disagreed with this belief and devoted most of his writing about Averroism to criticizing monopsychism. One of these works, essentially a commentary on [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[On the soul]]'', is ''De unitate intellectus contra Averroistas''.<ref>http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeUnitateIntellectus.htm</ref> Aquinas demonstrates how [[Averroes]] has misinterpreted Aristotle's argument, claiming that the correct interpretation is that an individual's [[nous|intellect]] cannot be independent of his or her physical body. {{quote|''(...) intellect, can be separated, not indeed from body, as the Commentator'' (Averroes) ''perversely interprets, but from other parts of the soul'' (...)|Aquinas}} ==Compare== *[[Collective unconscious]] *[[Neoplatonism]] *[[Open individualism]] *[[Panpsychism]] *[[Pantheism]] *''[[Unus mundus]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Theology]] [[Category:Theories of mind]] {{Buddhism-stub}}
